segment.source: Deploy Windows on a VHD (Native Boot)
segment.target: Deploy Windows on a VHD (Native Boot)

segment.source: Deploy Windows on a VHD (Native Boot)
segment.target: Deploy Windows on a VHD (Native Boot)

segment.source: Deploy Windows on a VHD (Native Boot)
segment.target: Deploy Windows on a VHD (Native Boot)

segment.source: Create and deploy virtual hard disks (VHDs) with native-boot capabilities to test devices or to manage multiple operating systems on a device without repartitioning the drive.
segment.target: Create and deploy virtual hard disks (VHDs) with native-boot capabilities to test devices or to manage multiple operating systems on a device without repartitioning the drive.

segment.source: Creating VHDs
segment.target: Creating VHDs

segment.source: You can create virtual hard disks (.vhd or .vhdx files) using the DiskPart tool or the Disk Management Microsoft Management Console (MMC).
segment.target: You can create virtual hard disks (.vhd or .vhdx files) using the DiskPart tool or the Disk Management Microsoft Management Console (MMC).

segment.source: You can create .vhdx files from PowerShell when you have the Hyper-V Manager Role installed.
segment.target: You can create .vhdx files from PowerShell when you have the Hyper-V Manager Role installed.

segment.source: You can attach the VHD so that it appears as a system drive that you can partition, format, and apply your operating system to.
segment.target: You can attach the VHD so that it appears as a system drive that you can partition, format, and apply your operating system to.

segment.source: Deploying VHDs
segment.target: Deploying VHDs

segment.source: You can deploy a supported Windows image to an attached VHD using disk-imaging software such as the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) tool.
segment.target: You can deploy a supported Windows image to an attached VHD using disk-imaging software such as the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) tool.

segment.source: The VHD can then be copied to one or more systems either to run in a virtual machine or for native boot.
segment.target: The VHD can then be copied to one or more systems either to run in a virtual machine or for native boot.

segment.source: For more information, see Download and install Windows PE (WinPE) so you can boot from a USB flash drive or an external USB hard drive.
segment.target: For more information, see Download and install Windows PE (WinPE) so you can boot from a USB flash drive or an external USB hard drive.

segment.source: On first native boot, the specialize configuration pass runs and computer-specific information is applied to the Windows operating system on the VHD.
segment.target: On first native boot, the specialize configuration pass runs and computer-specific information is applied to the Windows operating system on the VHD.

segment.source: The instance of the VHD cannot be copied onto another system or run in a virtual machine after the specialize configuration pass is completed.
segment.target: The instance of the VHD cannot be copied onto another system or run in a virtual machine after the specialize configuration pass is completed.

segment.source: The original VHD that has a Windows image can continue to be copied and deployed to multiple computers, if the image has already been prepared for installation using the Sysprep tool with the /specialize option.
segment.target: The original VHD that has a Windows image can continue to be copied and deployed to multiple computers, if the image has already been prepared for installation using the Sysprep tool with the /specialize option.

segment.source: You can also use an answer file to prepare the image for installation by using the Microsoft-Windows-Deployment | Generalize setting.
segment.target: You can also use an answer file to prepare the image for installation by using the Microsoft-Windows-Deployment | Generalize setting.

segment.source: For more information about the specialize and generalize configuration passes, see Windows Setup Configuration Passes.
segment.target: For more information about the specialize and generalize configuration passes, see Windows Setup Configuration Passes.

segment.source: For more information about how to use the Generalize setting in an answer file, see the Windows® Unattended Setup Reference.
segment.target: For more information about how to use the Generalize setting in an answer file, see the Windows® Unattended Setup Reference.

segment.source: The Windows Deployment Server role supports deployment of VHD image files in addition to .wim files.
segment.target: The Windows Deployment Server role supports deployment of VHD image files in addition to .wim files.

segment.source: Windows Deployment Server automates the network deployment of VHD images for native-boot usage.
segment.target: Windows Deployment Server automates the network deployment of VHD images for native-boot usage.

segment.source: Windows Deployment Server can be used to copy the VHD image to a local partition, and to configure the local Boot Configuration Data (BCD) for native boot from the VHD.
segment.target: Windows Deployment Server can be used to copy the VHD image to a local partition, and to configure the local Boot Configuration Data (BCD) for native boot from the VHD.

segment.target: Create and deploy a VHD on a destination computer.

segment.target: Download and install Windows PE (WinPE) so you can boot from a USB flash drive or an external USB hard drive

segment.target: Update a computer that has a Windows 7 or Windows 8 boot environment and add a VHD to the BCD configuration.
